data.title: Online Contents
data.text:
SPECIAL REPORT

America's Most Miserable Cities

By Kurt Badenhausen

Imagine living in a city with the country's highest rate for violent crimeand the second-highest rate for violent crime and the second-highest unemployment rate. As an added kicker you need more Superfund dollars allocated to your city than just about any other metro to clean up contaminated toxic waste sites.

This nightmare is reality for the residents of Detroit. The Motor City grabs the top spot on Forbes' inaugural list of America's Most Miserable Citites. But misery loves company. Who else among those living in America's 150 largest metropolitan areas qualifies? Take a look: www.forbes.com/miserable.

FORBES MAGAZINE

More arresting photos of India's underground child labor industry, with insight from reporter Megha Bahree, at www.forbes.com/coverstory.

PLUS

More tips on when retired couples should claim Social Security benefits, only at www.forbes.com/retirement.

FORBES ASIA

Farmed-Out Pharma. In the race to find the next billion-dollar drug, global drug companies like Pfizer and Merck have been looking to low-cost China for their research and development. WuXi PharmaTech, China's largest pharmaceutical r&d company, has taken the demand in stride.

VIDEO HIGHLIGHTS

StreetTalk with Bob Lenzner.

Integre Advisors founder Manny Weintraub on where to invest during a recession.

Davos.

Sergey Brin, Bono, Chad Hurley, Craig Barrett, Emma Thompson and others talk to Forbes.com's Camilla Webster at the recently concluded World Economic Forum.

Adventurer With Jim Clash.

Richard Branson and Burt Rutan unveil Virgin Galactic's next step to space tourism: SpaceShipTwo.

SportsMoney With Mike Ozanian.

The Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders discuss their new business ventures.

Celebrity Minute.

Lea Goldman introduces the cash queens who top Forbes' list of the highest-earning women in music.

Program Guide.

See our full listings of daily news bulletins and regular shows at www.forbes.com/video.
